title: NEGATIVE ADVERBIALS
subtitle: Never have I seen such beauty
explanation: When negative adverbials (never, rarely, seldom, not only, not once) start a sentence, we invert the subject and auxiliary verb. If there's no auxiliary, we add DO/DOES/DID. This creates emphasis and is common in formal writing and speech.
structure: Negative adverbial + auxiliary + subject + main verb

examples.before: I have <<never seen>> such beautiful scenery.
examples.after: **<<Never have I seen>>** such beautiful scenery.

examples.before: She had <<never been>> to Paris before.
examples.after: **<<Never had she been>>** to Paris before.

examples.before: We will <<never forget>> this experience.
examples.after: **<<Never will we forget>>** this experience.

examples.before: I have <<never read>> such a good book.
examples.after: **<<Never have I read>>** such a good book.

examples.before: They had <<never heard>> such a strange noise.
examples.after: **<<Never had they heard>>** such a strange noise.

examples.before: I will <<not go>> to that restaurant again.
examples.after: **<<Never again will I go>>** to that restaurant.

examples.before: She has <<not seen>> such a crowd before.
examples.after: **<<Never before has she seen>>** such a crowd.

examples.before: We will <<not make>> that mistake again.
examples.after: **<<Never again will we make>>** that mistake.

examples.before: He had <<not felt>> so happy before.
examples.after: **<<Never before had he felt>>** so happy.

examples.before: I have <<not tasted>> anything so delicious before.
examples.after: **<<Never before have I tasted>>** anything so delicious.

examples.before: I <<rarely enjoy>> a film so much.
examples.after: **<<Rarely do I enjoy>>** a film so much.

examples.before: She <<seldom complains>> about anything.
examples.after: **<<Seldom does she complain>>** about anything.

examples.before: We <<rarely see>> such dedication.
examples.after: **<<Rarely do we see>>** such dedication.

examples.before: He <<seldom visits>> his hometown.
examples.after: **<<Seldom does he visit>>** his hometown.

examples.before: They <<rarely agree>> on anything.
examples.after: **<<Rarely do they agree>>** on anything.

examples.before: She <<not only sings>> but also dances professionally.
examples.after: **<<Not only does she sing>>**, but she also dances professionally.

examples.before: I <<will not only go>> to the party, but I'll also help organize it.
examples.after: **<<Not only will I go>>** to the party, but I'll also help organize it.

examples.before: He <<has not only passed>> the exam but also got the highest score.
examples.after: **<<Not only has he passed>>** the exam, but he also got the highest score.

examples.before: They <<did not only win>> the match but also broke the record.
examples.after: **<<Not only did they win>>** the match, but they also broke the record.

examples.before: We <<have not only finished>> early but also under budget.
examples.after: **<<Not only have we finished>>** early, but also under budget.

title: STRONG NEGATIVES
subtitle: Under no circumstances can we accept this
mainTitle: At no time, In no way, Under no circumstances
explanation: Strong negative expressions (at no time, in no way, under no circumstances, by no means, on no account, on no condition) require inversion. These are very formal and emphatic ways to express prohibition or strong denial.
structure: Negative phrase + auxiliary/modal + subject + main verb

examples.before: I <<did not say>> you could borrow it at any time.
examples.after: **<<At no time did I say>>** you could borrow it.

examples.before: She <<has not mentioned>> leaving the company at any time.
examples.after: **<<At no time has she mentioned>>** leaving the company.

examples.before: We <<were not informed>> about the changes at any time.
examples.after: **<<At no time were we informed>>** about the changes.

examples.before: He <<did not suggest>> breaking the rules at any time.
examples.after: **<<At no time did he suggest>>** breaking the rules.

examples.before: They <<have not considered>> giving up at any time.
examples.after: **<<At no time have they considered>>** giving up.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: Under no circumstances / On no account

examples.before: We <<cannot smoke>> in here under any circumstances.
examples.after: **<<Under no circumstances can we smoke>>** in here.

examples.before: You <<must not reveal>> this information under any circumstances.
examples.after: **<<Under no circumstances must you reveal>>** this information.

examples.before: Students <<should not use>> this exit on any account.
examples.after: **<<On no account should students use>>** this exit.

examples.before: Visitors <<may not enter>> this area under any circumstances.
examples.after: **<<Under no circumstances may visitors enter>>** this area.

examples.before: We <<will not accept>> late submissions on any account.
examples.after: **<<On no account will we accept>>** late submissions.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: In no way / By no means

examples.before: I <<do not blame>> you for this accident in any way.
examples.after: **<<In no way do I blame>>** you for this accident.

examples.before: It <<is not easy>> to use inversion correctly by any means.
examples.after: **<<By no means is it easy>>** to use inversion correctly.

examples.before: This <<is not>> the end of the matter by any means.
examples.after: **<<By no means is this>>** the end of the matter.

examples.before: We <<are not>> finished with this project by any means.
examples.after: **<<By no means are we>>** finished with this project.

examples.before: She <<does not>> support this decision in any way.
examples.after: **<<In no way does she support>>** this decision.

examples.before: Customers <<should not be>> allowed to use this exit on any condition.
examples.after: **<<On no condition should customers be>>** allowed to use this exit.

examples.before: Children <<must not be>> left alone on any condition.
examples.after: **<<On no condition must children be>>** left alone.

examples.before: This information <<can be>> disclosed on no condition.
examples.after: **<<On no condition can this information be>>** disclosed.

examples.before: Employees <<should>> discuss salaries with each other on no condition.
examples.after: **<<On no condition should employees discuss>>** salaries with each other.

examples.before: We <<will>> compromise on safety on no condition.
examples.after: **<<On no condition will we compromise>>** on safety.

title: ONLY STRUCTURES
subtitle: Only when he explained did I understand
mainTitle: Only when, Only after, Only then
explanation: When 'only' is followed by a time expression (only when, only after, only then, only later, only once) at the beginning of a sentence, we invert the subject and auxiliary in the main clause. The inversion happens in the MAIN clause, not in the 'only' clause.
structure: Only + time expression, auxiliary + subject + main verb

examples.before: I <<understood>> inversion only when he explained it.
examples.after: **Only when he explained it <<did I understand>>** inversion.

examples.before: She <<realized>> her mistake only when she saw the results.
examples.after: **Only when she saw the results <<did she realize>>** her mistake.

examples.before: We <<knew>> the truth only when the report was published.
examples.after: **Only when the report was published <<did we know>>** the truth.

examples.before: He <<felt>> relief only when the exam was over.
examples.after: **Only when the exam was over <<did he feel>>** relief.

examples.before: They <<appreciated>> what they had only when it was gone.
examples.after: **Only when it was gone <<did they appreciate>>** what they had.

examples.before: It <<started>> raining only after I had left.
examples.after: **Only after I had left <<did it start>>** raining.

examples.before: She <<discovered>> the error only after she had submitted the report.
examples.after: **Only after she had submitted the report <<did she discover>>** the error.

examples.before: We <<learned>> the news only after everyone else knew.
examples.after: **Only after everyone else knew <<did we learn>>** the news.

examples.before: He <<understood>> the importance only after it was too late.
examples.after: **Only after it was too late <<did he understand>>** the importance.

examples.before: I <<realized>> I had forgotten my keys only after I left the house.
examples.after: **Only after I left the house <<did I realize>>** I had forgotten my keys.

examples.before: I <<understood>> the problem only then.
examples.after: **Only then <<did I understand>>** the problem.

examples.before: She <<realized>> her mistake only later.
examples.after: **Only later <<did she realize>>** her mistake.

examples.before: We <<discovered>> the truth only then.
examples.after: **Only then <<did we discover>>** the truth.

examples.before: He <<saw>> the solution only then.
examples.after: **Only then <<did he see>>** the solution.

examples.before: They <<understood>> what had happened only later.
examples.after: **Only later <<did they understand>>** what had happened.

examples.before: We <<can>> solve this problem only by working together.
examples.after: **Only by working together <<can we solve>>** this problem.

examples.before: You <<will>> succeed only through hard work.
examples.after: **Only through hard work <<will you succeed>>**.

examples.before: She <<achieved>> success only by never giving up.
examples.after: **Only by never giving up <<did she achieve>>** success.

examples.before: We <<can>> understand this only by examining the evidence.
examples.after: **Only by examining the evidence <<can we understand>>** this.

examples.before: He <<learned>> the truth only through persistence.
examples.after: **Only through persistence <<did he learn>>** the truth.

title: TIME SEQUENCES
subtitle: No sooner had he arrived than the meeting started
mainTitle: No sooner, Hardly, Scarcely, Not until
explanation: These expressions describe immediate sequences or delayed actions. No sooner uses THAN, while Hardly/Scarcely use WHEN. They typically use past perfect in the inverted clause. 'Not until' emphasizes when something finally happened.
structure: No sooner/Hardly/Scarcely + had + subject + past participle + than/when...

examples.before: He <<had arrived>>, and the meeting started immediately.
examples.after: **<<No sooner had he arrived>>** than the meeting started.

examples.before: We <<had gone>> to bed, and the phone rang immediately.
examples.after: **<<No sooner had we gone>>** to bed than the phone rang.

examples.before: She <<had left>>, and it started raining immediately.
examples.after: **<<No sooner had she left>>** than it started raining.

examples.before: I <<had sat>> down, and someone knocked on the door immediately.
examples.after: **<<No sooner had I sat>>** down than someone knocked on the door.

examples.before: They <<had finished>> eating, and the waiter brought the bill immediately.
examples.after: **<<No sooner had they finished>>** eating than the waiter brought the bill.

examples.before: She <<had sat>> down, and the phone rang immediately.
examples.after: **<<Hardly had she sat>>** down when the phone rang.

examples.before: I <<had entered>> the room, and everyone stopped talking immediately.
examples.after: **<<Scarcely had I entered>>** the room when everyone stopped talking.

examples.before: We <<had started>> the meeting, and the fire alarm went off immediately.
examples.after: **<<Hardly had we started>>** the meeting when the fire alarm went off.

examples.before: He <<had begun>> speaking, and people started leaving immediately.
examples.after: **<<Scarcely had he begun>>** speaking when people started leaving.

examples.before: They <<had arrived>>, and the storm broke immediately.
examples.after: **<<Hardly had they arrived>>** when the storm broke.

examples.before: We <<did not get>> home until midnight.
examples.after: **<<Not until midnight did we get>>** home.

examples.before: She <<did not understand>> until he explained it.
examples.after: **<<Not until he explained it did she understand>>**.

examples.before: I <<did not realize>> the problem until it was too late.
examples.after: **<<Not until it was too late did I realize>>** the problem.

examples.before: They <<did not discover>> the mistake until the next day.
examples.after: **<<Not until the next day did they discover>>** the mistake.

examples.before: He <<did not feel>> better until he took the medicine.
examples.after: **<<Not until he took the medicine did he feel>>** better.

examples.before: I <<have>> seldom seen such determination.
examples.after: **<<Seldom have I seen>>** such determination.

examples.before: She <<has>> hardly ever complained about anything.
examples.after: **<<Hardly ever has she complained>>** about anything.

examples.before: We <<have>> seldom experienced such poor service.
examples.after: **<<Seldom have we experienced>>** such poor service.

examples.before: He <<does>> hardly ever visit his parents.
examples.after: **<<Hardly ever does he visit>>** his parents.

examples.before: They <<have>> seldom been so impressed.
examples.after: **<<Seldom have they been>>** so impressed.

title: NOT SINCE
subtitle: Not since childhood have I felt so happy
explanation: Use 'not since' + time reference to emphasize how long it has been since something happened. This structure requires inversion with present perfect or past perfect. It emphasizes the length of time that has passed.
structure: Not since + time reference + have/has/had + subject + past participle

examples.before: I <<have not felt>> so happy since I was a child.
examples.after: **<<Not since I was a child have I felt>>** so happy.

examples.before: She <<has not visited>> us since 2010.
examples.after: **<<Not since 2010 has she visited>>** us.

examples.before: We <<have not seen>> such a good performance since last year.
examples.after: **<<Not since last year have we seen>>** such a good performance.

examples.before: He <<has not played>> so well since his injury.
examples.after: **<<Not since his injury has he played>>** so well.

examples.before: They <<have not been>> so busy since they opened the shop.
examples.after: **<<Not since they opened the shop have they been>>** so busy.

examples.before: I <<have not eaten>> so much since I was a teenager.
examples.after: **<<Not since I was a teenager have I eaten>>** so much.

examples.before: She <<has not studied>> so hard since university.
examples.after: **<<Not since university has she studied>>** so hard.

examples.before: We <<have not worked>> so intensely since we started the company.
examples.after: **<<Not since we started the company have we worked>>** so intensely.

examples.before: He <<has not felt>> so nervous since his first day at school.
examples.after: **<<Not since his first day at school has he felt>>** so nervous.

examples.before: They <<have not laughed>> so much since their wedding day.
examples.after: **<<Not since their wedding day have they laughed>>** so much.

examples.before: I <<have not been>> so worried since the accident.
examples.after: **<<Not since the accident have I been>>** so worried.

examples.before: She <<has not traveled>> since the pandemic began.
examples.after: **<<Not since the pandemic began has she traveled>>**.

examples.before: We <<have not faced>> such a challenge since the crisis.
examples.after: **<<Not since the crisis have we faced>>** such a challenge.

examples.before: He <<has not performed>> since his retirement.
examples.after: **<<Not since his retirement has he performed>>**.

examples.before: They <<have not met>> since graduation.
examples.after: **<<Not since graduation have they met>>**.

title: SO & SUCH
subtitle: So beautiful was the view that we stayed for hours
explanation: When we want to emphasize 'so' or 'such' at the beginning of a sentence, we invert the subject and verb. 'So + adjective/adverb' inverts with BE or auxiliary. 'Such + be' inverts to emphasize the noun phrase. This is formal and literary.
structure: So + adjective/adverb + auxiliary/be + subject OR Such + be + noun phrase

examples.before: The view <<was so beautiful>> that we stayed for hours.
examples.after: **<<So beautiful was the view>>** that we stayed for hours.

examples.before: The problem <<was so complex>> that nobody could solve it.
examples.after: **<<So complex was the problem>>** that nobody could solve it.

examples.before: The noise <<was so loud>> that I couldn't concentrate.
examples.after: **<<So loud was the noise>>** that I couldn't concentrate.

examples.before: The storm <<was so severe>> that all flights were cancelled.
examples.after: **<<So severe was the storm>>** that all flights were cancelled.

examples.before: Her performance <<was so impressive>> that everyone applauded.
examples.after: **<<So impressive was her performance>>** that everyone applauded.

examples.before: She spoke <<so fondly>> about her parents.
examples.after: **<<So fondly did she speak>>** about her parents.

examples.before: He worked <<so hard>> that he fell ill.
examples.after: **<<So hard did he work>>** that he fell ill.

examples.before: They argued <<so loudly>> that the neighbors complained.
examples.after: **<<So loudly did they argue>>** that the neighbors complained.

examples.before: She sang <<so beautifully>> that everyone was moved.
examples.after: **<<So beautifully did she sing>>** that everyone was moved.

examples.before: He ran <<so quickly>> that nobody could catch him.
examples.after: **<<So quickly did he run>>** that nobody could catch him.

examples.before: It <<was such a beautiful day>> that we went to the beach.
examples.after: **<<Such was the beauty of the day>>** that we went to the beach.

examples.before: His anger <<was such>> that everyone left the room.
examples.after: **<<Such was his anger>>** that everyone left the room.

examples.before: The confusion <<was such>> that nobody knew what to do.
examples.after: **<<Such was the confusion>>** that nobody knew what to do.

examples.before: Her talent <<was such>> that she became famous overnight.
examples.after: **<<Such was her talent>>** that she became famous overnight.

examples.before: The excitement <<was such>> that people couldn't sleep.
examples.after: **<<Such was the excitement>>** that people couldn't sleep.

examples.before: The situation <<has become so desperate>> that action is needed.
examples.after: **<<So desperate has the situation become>>** that action is needed.

examples.before: Prices <<have risen so dramatically>> that people can't afford food.
examples.after: **<<So dramatically have prices risen>>** that people can't afford food.

examples.before: The technology <<has advanced so rapidly>> that we can't keep up.
examples.after: **<<So rapidly has the technology advanced>>** that we can't keep up.

examples.before: His health <<has deteriorated so badly>> that he needs constant care.
examples.after: **<<So badly has his health deteriorated>>** that he needs constant care.

examples.before: The project <<has grown so much>> that we need more staff.
examples.after: **<<So much has the project grown>>** that we need more staff.

title: CONDITIONAL
subtitle: Had I known, I would have helped
explanation: In formal English, we can invert conditionals by removing 'if' and inverting the auxiliary. Had = If + past perfect. Were = If + past simple (subjunctive). Should = If + should. This is very common in formal and literary English.

examples.before: <<If I had known>>, I would have helped you.
examples.after: **<<Had I known>>**, I would have helped you.

examples.before: <<If she had studied>> harder, she would have passed.
examples.after: **<<Had she studied>>** harder, she would have passed.

examples.before: <<If we had left>> earlier, we wouldn't have missed the train.
examples.after: **<<Had we left>>** earlier, we wouldn't have missed the train.

examples.before: <<If he had listened>> to advice, he wouldn't be in this situation.
examples.after: **<<Had he listened>>** to advice, he wouldn't be in this situation.

examples.before: <<If they had known>> about the problem, they would have fixed it.
examples.after: **<<Had they known>>** about the problem, they would have fixed it.

examples.before: <<If I were>> rich, I would travel the world.
examples.after: **<<Were I rich>>**, I would travel the world.

examples.before: <<If she were>> here, she would know what to do.
examples.after: **<<Were she here>>**, she would know what to do.

examples.before: <<If we were>> in charge, things would be different.
examples.after: **<<Were we in charge>>**, things would be different.

examples.before: <<If he were>> taller, he could be a basketball player.
examples.after: **<<Were he taller>>**, he could be a basketball player.

examples.before: <<If it were>> not for your help, I would have failed.
examples.after: **<<Were it not for your help>>**, I would have failed.

examples.before: <<If you should need>> help, call me.
examples.after: **<<Should you need>>** help, call me.

examples.before: <<If she should arrive>> early, tell her to wait.
examples.after: **<<Should she arrive>>** early, tell her to wait.

examples.before: <<If we should hear>> any news, we'll let you know.
examples.after: **<<Should we hear>>** any news, we'll let you know.

examples.before: <<If he should change>> his mind, inform me immediately.
examples.after: **<<Should he change>>** his mind, inform me immediately.

examples.before: <<If they should decide>> to come, there's room for them.
examples.after: **<<Should they decide>>** to come, there's room for them.

examples.before: <<If I had been>> born rich, I would be living differently now.
examples.after: **<<Had I been>>** born rich, I would be living differently now.

examples.before: <<If she were>> more confident, she would have applied for the job.
examples.after: **<<Were she>>** more confident, she would have applied for the job.

examples.before: <<If you should find>> my keys, please return them.
examples.after: **<<Should you find>>** my keys, please return them.

examples.before: <<If he had taken>> my advice, he wouldn't be in trouble now.
examples.after: **<<Had he taken>>** my advice, he wouldn't be in trouble now.

examples.before: <<If it were not>> for modern medicine, many would die.
examples.after: **<<Were it not>>** for modern medicine, many would die.

title: NOWHERE & NOT ONLY
subtitle: Nowhere can you find such beauty
explanation: These expressions create strong emphasis by combining negation with inversion. 'Nowhere' means 'in no place', 'Little' means 'barely/hardly'. They are formal and emphatic structures that add drama and emphasis to writing and speech.

examples.before: You <<cannot find>> a city as beautiful as Funchal anywhere.
examples.after: **<<Nowhere can you find>>** a city as beautiful as Funchal.

examples.before: You <<will not see>> such scenery anywhere else.
examples.after: **<<Nowhere else will you see>>** such scenery.

examples.before: We <<could not find>> better service anywhere.
examples.after: **<<Nowhere could we find>>** better service.

examples.before: She <<has not been>> happier anywhere else.
examples.after: **<<Nowhere else has she been>>** happier.

examples.before: They <<had not found>> such hospitality anywhere before.
examples.after: **<<Nowhere had they found>>** such hospitality before.

examples.before: They <<did not know>> what awaited them.
examples.after: **<<Little did they know>>** what awaited them.

examples.before: She <<did not realize>> the impact of her decision.
examples.after: **<<Little did she realize>>** the impact of her decision.

examples.before: We <<did not suspect>> that he was lying.
examples.after: **<<Little did we suspect>>** that he was lying.

examples.before: He <<did not imagine>> that he would become famous.
examples.after: **<<Little did he imagine>>** that he would become famous.

examples.before: I <<did not expect>> to see you here.
examples.after: **<<Little did I expect>>** to see you here.

examples.before: She <<does not only teach>> English but also French.
examples.after: **<<Not only does she teach>>** English, but also French.

examples.before: He <<has not only lost>> his job but also his home.
examples.after: **<<Not only has he lost>>** his job, but also his home.

examples.before: We <<did not only finish>> on time but also under budget.
examples.after: **<<Not only did we finish>>** on time, but also under budget.

examples.before: They <<will not only attend>> but also present at the conference.
examples.after: **<<Not only will they attend>>**, but they will also present at the conference.

examples.before: I <<have not only read>> the book but also seen the film.
examples.after: **<<Not only have I read>>** the book, but I've also seen the film.

sets.setTitle: Set 4: Not a single / Not one

examples.before: I <<did not see>> a single person on the street.
examples.after: **<<Not a single person did I see>>** on the street.

examples.before: She <<has not made>> a single mistake in her exam.
examples.after: **<<Not a single mistake has she made>>** in her exam.

examples.before: We <<did not receive>> one complaint about the service.
examples.after: **<<Not one complaint did we receive>>** about the service.
